Award.AbstractNarration:
This proposal seeks to acquire a state-of-the-art multimodal microscope that will enable visualization of biological tissues at very high resolution without the need to section them. One of the imaging modalities, coherent anti-Stokes Raman scattering (CARS) microscopy, has emerged as a unique non-invasive visualization tool for monitoring changes in the lipid and mineral composition of biological samples. The ability to study these aspects of the samples in combination with surrounding cellular and extracellular components will have a significant impact on a wide range of important biomedical problems, such as diabetes, cardiovascular disease, obesity, cancer, and brain function. Thus, there are important potential societal benefits. In addition, this will be a unique shared resource facility for Tufts University and will be made available to the broader academic and industry community of the Boston area for research purposes. Finally, this microscope will serve as an outstanding educational tool that will be incorporated in laboratory courses and workshops to train undergraduate and graduate students as well as other members of the academic and research community.

The proposed multi-modal confocal/two-photon/ CARS microscope will be used to address key questions in which dynamic changes in the mineral, lipid and potentially water content of biological tissue specimens in response to interactions with their surrounding environment play a key role. One of the main properties of CARS that enables these studies is its ability to provide strong, chemically specific signals without the need for exogenous dyes. The latter may be tedious or impossible to incorporate in a three-dimensional specimen or the agent specificity may change over time leading to artifacts. CARS also offers inherent optical sectioning capabilities, needed to examine in vitro, ex vivo and in vivo tissue specimens. In fact, because of the highly scattering nature of lipids, CARS is needed for detailed studies of even two-dimensional cell specimens. Finally, compared to confocal Raman for example, CARS offers superior signal to background, which in turn enables fast imaging. As a result, we expect that the requested CARS microscope will provide important insights in: a) identifying and monitoring distinct adipose tissue type depots in response to anti-obesity interventions, b) understanding the effects of different engineered extracellular matrices and bioelectric signaling mechanisms on neuronal growth and repair, c) regulating lipid droplet dynamics, metabolism and obesity, d) understanding lipidoid-mediated biomacromolecule delivery, d) dental tissue development and regeneration, e) mineral deposit accumulation during calcific aortic valve disease, f) adipose cell-matrix interactions during breast cancer development and in response to novel treatments, and g) characterization of the pericellular brush of cancer cells.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Under this grant, an advanced microscopic imaging facility was established at Tufts University (Medford, MA).  Its primary goal was to serve the research needs of investigators from multiple departments throughout the University and potentially from other institutions and businesses in the Greater Boston area. Its state-of-the-art suite of laser excitation mechanisms and sensitive photodetectors has allowed for efficient 3D imaging of live cells and tissue surfaces.  The chemical specificity afforded by its imaging modalities, coupled with its capacity to discern subcellular features as small as 0.3mm, is greatly enhancing the understanding of basic biochemical processes involved in major diseases, such as cancer, obesity and heart failure. 

 

Although other microscopic imaging facilities already existed across Tufts University?s main campuses (in Boston, Medford and Grafton, MA), our facility is the only one which provides the capacity to excite specimens with high power, tunable near-infrared lasers (a technique known as multiphoton imaging, as opposed to standard confocal microscopy).  The major advantages conferred by multiphoton microscopy are:  (i) Increased chemical specificity of the features imaged, due to the tunability of the laser light source; (ii) Increased sensitivity and speed of imaging, due to the high power of the pulsed laser; (iii) Less photodamage of biological cells and tissue, and deeper penetration below the tissue surface, due to the long wavelength of the near-infrared laser.

 

In addition, our microscope is uniquely equipped with a specialized imaging system, based on a different type of pulsed near-infrared laser, known as Coherent Anti-Stokes Raman Spectroscopy (CARS).  This technique is capable of identifying specific chemical bonds and is particularly efficient at detecting microscopic amounts of fatty, or lipid, molecules ?thus rendering it highly useful in the study of obesity and fat metabolism at a cellular level.  No other core imaging facility in the Greater Boston area offers this service.  Access to CARS microscopic imaging has allowed one group of researchers at Tufts University to elucidate biochemical pathways in non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD), a major chronic liver disease in Western countries which is strongly correlated with obesity (Fig. 1) [1]. 

 

Another area of research strongly supported by our microscopic imaging facility is the development of bioengineered tissues.  The capability for doing noninvasive, live imaging of cells embedded in various bioengineered scaffolds, over extended periods of time, will greatly facilitate optimization of these systems into viable tissue replacements, or as surrogates for the study of diseased human tissues. The Tufts department of Biomedical Engineering is a world leader in the development of bioengineered tissues derived from silk protein, and access to our imaging facility is fundamental to the verification and validation of their various designs. Figure 2 illustrates one such application, in which CARS and multiphoton microscopy were used to monitor the organization and longterm viability of lipoaspirate seeded into a 3D model of human adipose tissue [2].

 

The standard confocal microscopy capabilities of our microscope are also commonly used to monitor the viability of cells seeded into engineered tissues.  Commercial dyes may be used to stain specific cellular organelles, and the multiple laser excitation and detection schemes available in our microscope can then provide simultaneous imaging of multiple subcellular features throughout the bioengineered constructs.  Figure 3 shows confocal fluorescence images obtained from a biomaterial matrix designed to mimic human skin.  The degree of innervation in these tissue models ? a key element of the success of these constructs ? was examined via a combination of cell nuclear stains (blue) and neuron-specific stains (green and red). In addition, a fourth dye specifically targeting the location of macrophage cells (yellow) helped to map the immune response of cells throughout the construct [3].

 

Other areas of biomedical significance currently being pursued in our facility include:

      i.         Using Second Harmonic Generation (SHG), an aspect of multiphoton imaging, for monitoring degradation of collagen fibers in the extracellular matrix of cancerous tissues

    ii.         Using CARS to study the calcification of human arterial valves

   iii.         Exploring novel biomarkers for neurodegenerative disease

 

During the summer of 2017, our imaging facility was relocated to a new Science & Engineering Complex, centrally located on the Tufts Medford campus. The move has increased the visibility and accessibility of the imaging center, and has expanded its user base into other departments (e.g., Biology and Chemistry).  Since the microscope was acquired, a total of 4 undergraduates, 17 graduate students and 10 postdoctoral associates and visiting scientists have been trained in its use.

 

Finally, the imaging facility has also served to support and promote the educational goals, both graduate and undergraduate, at Tufts University.  Lab modules in confocal, multiphoton and CARS microscopy were developed and used for class demonstrations and student trainings for a yearly course on Quantitative Materials Characterization (BME56/256).

 

[1] Cell Reports, 23(4), p.1099-1111 (2018).

[2] Tissue Engineering & Regenerative Medicine, 12(3), p.840-847 (2018).

[3] Biomaterials, 24 April 2018,  https://doi.org/10.1016/j.biomaterials.2018.04.044
